End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy grass for cows and pig food

loans.name: Mrs. Kim Srey Mao Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people in Toek Khlaing Village in Kandal Province make up the Village Bank LoA., led by Village Bank President Mrs. Kim S. M., who was selected by the members. Mrs. M.’s living conditions are poor because her household makes only a small income. She is a vegetable farmer and cow breeder with three cows. Her family has only one bike for travelling to the field and local market. Her husband, Mr. Keo SoC., is a fishermA. who needs more fish nets to improve his business, Mrs. M. is requesting a loA. to buy additional nets  to increase household income.  

Mrs. S. M. is 37 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory earning $38 per month while the remaining three are attending school. 

This is a village bank loA. consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fish nets for her husband's business

loans.name: Mrs.ccheam Yan Group

texts.en:
This loan group, led by Mrs. Cheam Y., consists of five people living in Yok Bath Village. The members will use the loan in a variety of businesses; for example Mrs. Y. wants to invest in her water lily sales, which earns her $3 to $4 a day. In her household, there is one motorbike which her husband, Mr. Chea Y., uses to go to his work place. He is a construction worker who can make $4 a day to support his family. 

Mrs. Cheam Y. is 54 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a construction worker.  Two others are  at home doing housework while the remaining two are attending school.

loans.use: To buy more more water lilies for resale.

loans.name: Ni Nengah Sotri

texts.id:
Setelah menyelesaikan pinjaman periode yang pertama, Ni Wayan Sotri kembali melanjutkan pinjaman periode kedua. Hal ini dilakukannya karena ia masih memerlukan dana untuk mengembangkan usahanya. Dana pinjaman dipakai untuk melanjutkan usaha dalam menjual sarana sembahyang. Saat ini dana yang didapatnya digunakan untuk membeli bahan baku pembuatan Canang dalam jumlah yang cukup banyak karena Ni Wayan Sotri mendapat pesanan dalam jumlah yang banyak. Selain untuk persembahyangan sehari – hari, juga melayani sembahyang  besar / paket Otonan dan Odalan ( upacara agama Hindu di Bali ).
            Dengan bergabungnya dengan Yayasan Dinari, Ni Nengah Sotri tidak hanya memperoleh modal dana tetapi juga memperoleh pembinaan - pembinaan yang tentunya diharapkan dapat meningkatkan pengetahuan dan usahanya.
Keuntungan  bersih dalam sehari mencapai Rp. 40.000.- s/d 50.000.- Keuntungan tersebut dipakai untuk mencukupi keperluan keluarganya, ditabung dan untuk modal usaha.

loans.use: Menambah modal usaha untuk membeli bahan baku

loans.name: Ni Komang Sriani

texts.id:
Melalui  organisasi Tempek ( sebuah organisasi adat ) yang ada didesanya, Ni  Komang Sriani mendapatkan dana dari Yayasan DINARI untuk periode ke dua. Pinjaman pertama dirasakan sangat membantu usahanya, karena ingin mengembangkan usahanya, Ni Komang Sriani mengajukan permohonan untuk mendapatkan pinjaman yang kedua.  Dana tersebut sangat berarti dalam menambah modal usaha dalam usaha jual beli hasil pertanian. Dalam sehari Ni Komang Sriani dapat membeli coklat, pisang, kelapa dan hasil kebun lainnya. Esok paginya, Ni Komang Sriani akan menjualnya barang dagangannya dipasar ataupun beberapa pelanggan yang biasa membeli darinya. Keuntungan bersih dalam setiap hari dapat mencapai Rp. 25.000.- s/d 30.000.- 
Dari Usaha seperti inilah Komang Sriani dapat menggantungkan hidupnya bersama suaminya, Darma Kantun, yang tidak bekerja dan hanya mengandalkan hasil kebunnya sendiri.

loans.use: Menambah modal usaha

loans.name: Cheun

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheun R. is a 50 year old farmer, who also sells groceries. She sells groceries near her house in the Village. Her husband, Mr. Touch Phal, 61, is a farmer and always helps with his wife's business. She has four children, one is married and the three others live with them at home and help with their parents businesses. They all live together in Ptas Rong Commune, Pursat Province. 

Mrs. Cheun is requesting a loan of KHR 2000000 Riel (US$500) to purchase more grocery stock for resale and fertilizer to use for growing rice in the farming season. She believes that this loan will increase her daily income and support her family's living expenses. Mrs. Cheun's husband is pictured because Cheun was unavailable.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery stock as well as fertilizer

loans.name: Mr. Eim Sarin Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank President of this loan is Mrs. Eim S., who owns a small restaurant where she sells Chinese noodles to both villagers and visitors. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Eim S. is requesting a loan to buy more beef and other ingredients to cook delicious noodle dishes for her customers. Her husband, Mr. Meas Sophy, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make $5 a day to support his family. 

Mrs. Eim S. is 36 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a waiter while another is a carpenter. The third one is enrolled in school while the youngest is yet too young to work or stuD..

The 16 people in Slab Ta Oan Village in Kandal Province who comprise this loan group will use the loan for a variety of purposes.

loans.use: To buy more beef and other ingredients to cook delicious noodle dishes for her customers

loans.name: Mrs. Saom Sopheak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people in Toek Khlaing Village in Kandal Province are members of this loan group. All the members are married and have various uses for the loan which they will obtain. For instance, Mrs. Saom S., the Village Bank President, is requesting a loan to hire a labourer with oxen to plow her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Sok Sorphorn, owns a small grocery store in the local village and also helps his wife on the land. 

Mrs. Saom S. is 35 years old and the mother of two children who both attend school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. All the members have end-of-term loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To hire a labourer with oxen to plow her rice field

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom E. is 40-year-old grocery seller in her village while her husband, Pen Sokun, is a 51-year-old policeman. Sreymom has been selling since 2002 and has two children; one is farmer and another one is studying. They are living in Snam Preah Commune, Pursat Province.

Because she wants to grow her grocery business, Mrs. Sreymom talked with her husband to find the capital to purchase more grocery stocks for resale and also more fertilizer to use for the farming business. Now Sreymom decided to request a loan of US$500. Sreymom hopes the capital will improve her business income to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery stocks for resale and also more fertilizer for farming business

loans.name: Mrs. Morm Sam Oeun Group

texts.en:
The four women in Khsom Village in Kandal Province who have formed a loan group will use the loan for a variety of purposes. The group leader, Mrs. Morm S. O., grows corn, assisted by her husband, Mr. Chon S. Art, and since her business is doing well, she is requesting a loan to buy more corn seeds to cultivate. In addition, she has one cow for breeding.

Mrs. Morm S. O. is 50 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory earning $50 each per month. The remaining two are attending school.

loans.use: To buy more corn seeds to cultivate

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun H. is a 65 year old farmer, who lives with her husband and three children. She has been farming for about twenty years, and typically earns US$2.00 per day. Mrs. Thoeun has seven children, three of tH. are tailors, and they all live in Snam Pras Commune, Pursat Province. 

Mrs. Thoeun consulted with her husband, and decided to seek a loan of US$600 to purchase two oxen and more fertilizer for her farming business. The loan will help to increase her income and sustain their daily lives.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen and more fertilizer

loans.name: Kimleng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimleng S. is 38 years old and sells sugar cane juice and raises pigs, earning about US$3.00 per day. Her husband, Mr. Ok Kosal, 30 years old, sells icecream door to door, and also distills alcohol at home, earning US$3.00 per day. They both have two children, two of whom are students, and they live in Snam Pras Commune, Pursat Province.

Mrs. Kimleng decided to request a loan US$500 to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband's business and to also purchase five pigs to breed. Mrs. Kimleng hopes that the loan will improve her husband's business and increase the family's income to support its daily expenses. Mrs. Kimleng is pictured next to her husband who is sitting on the motorcycle with the trailer of icecream.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and five pigs to breed

loans.name: Sopha

texts.en:
Mr. Sopha K. is 30 years old and works for a local organization in Pursat Province, earning about US$3.00 per day. He lives with his wife and his children in Snam Preagh Commune, Pursat Province. His wife, Mrs. Ses Chan, is 20 years old and sells groceries and grows rice, earning approximately US$5.00 per day. 

Mr. Sopha is requesting a loan US$600 to purchase more grocery stock for his wife's business. He will use the rest of the loan to purchase fertilizer for his wife's rice crop. The loan will help to increase the family's income to support their daily expenses. Mr. Sopha's wife is pictured because of Sopha was unavailable.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery stock and fertilizer

loans.name: Mr. Duch Chark Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, consisting of 26 people, is located in Kandal Leu Village in Kandal Province and Mr. Duch C. is the Village Bank President selected by the members. The members plan to use the loan for a variety of purposes; for example, Mr. Duch C. plans to buy fertilizer for his farmland and more bean seeds for cultivation.  His wife, Mrs. Khuth Saron, helps her husband on the farm.

Mr. C. is 42 years old and the father of four children, two of whom help their parents in the field while the other two are attending high school. 

In this village bank loan, one member has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. This member is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for the farm and more bean seeds for cultivating.

loans.name: Mrs. Chea Kunthea Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of four people living in Kos Prak Village in Kandal Province led by Mrs. Chea K., who was selected by the members and is the 27-year-old mother of two preschool-aged children.  She and her husband, Mr. Chea Suy, are fishermen in the local village. Mrs. K. is requesting a loan to buy more fish nets in order to increase their catch.  In addition to this business, Mrs. K. is also a cow breeder currently raising two cows.

loans.use: To buy more fish nets in order to increase their catch

loans.name: Pleanh

texts.en:
Mrs. Pleanh P. is a 45 year old widowed farmer, who grows rice. She has been farming since 1990 in Phteah Rung Commune, and typically earns about $1.50 per day. She has no children and lives in Ptas Rong Commune, Siem Pursat Province. Although she lives alone she is delighted with her daily farm work, which is the main income for covering the family's expenses.

The farming season has begun and she needs capital for her business, so she decided to request a loan of US$125 to expand her farmland. She hopes that the loan will generate more income to sustain her daily life.

loans.use: To expand her farmland

loans.name: Mr. Bu Hun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank Loan, which consists of 23 members, is located in Peam Prochum Village in Kandal Province, and Mrs. Bu H. is the Village Bank President. All of the members plan to use the loan for a variety of purposes. For instance, Mrs. Bu H. is a cow and pig breeder, and as the animals grow bigger, she lacks sufficient money to buy food for them; she therefore is requesting a loan to buy grass and pig food for her animals. Aside from this business, she is a farmer who cultivates rice and vegetables while her husband, Mr. Mich H., assists her in order to improve their living conditions together. 

Mrs. Bu H. is 50 years old and the mother of seven children, one of whom is a farmer while another two are employed in a garment factoR.. Another is an electrician while the remaining three are attending high school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy grass and pig food for her animals.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sorn S. is a farmer who grows rice, and is 43 years old. She has been growing rice since 1980 and earns US$1.50 per day. She lives with her husband and one child in Pteah Rong Commune, Pursat Province, and they work hard every day.

The farming season has arrived, so Sorn is seeking a loan of US$100 to purchase fertilizer and increase the farm's yield for her business. She hopes that the loan will increase her income and sustain their family. Sorn and her husband are pictured.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom baji lives in Shah Rukn-e-Alam, a part of the city of Multan. Multan is famous for its historical places and handicrafts. Kalsoom baji is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband, T. M., is a contractor who makes buildings and houses.

Kalsoom baji has a decorative embroidery business. She bears all the expenses of making dresses and sells them in a big market. She has been in this profession for the last 5 years. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is running out of stock now. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to buy material (cloth and colored thread) to expand the business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Parveen baji and Khursheed baji each want a loan to buy cloth for their boutiques. Shakeela baji wants a loan to buy scrap (plastic bottles and paper) for her scrap business. Martha baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra baji is the wife of S. M. and lives in a place named Shah Rukn-e-Alam. Shah Rukn-e-Alam is a part of the famous city Multan. Multan is famous for its historical places and handicrafts. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. All of her children are getting an education.

Bushra baji and her husband are very kind persons and their wish is to give their children a better future, because they know the value of education. Her husband works in a factory. Bushra baji has a clothes business. She buys clothes of good quality from her native city, Multan. She has been in this business for the last 8 years. She successfully completed her first two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to re-sell.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Kaniz baji and Afshan baji each want a loan to buy cosmetics for their beauty parlors. Niamat baji wants a loan to buy scrap (plastic bottles, papers) for her scrap business. Azra baji wants a loan to buy material (beads, cloth, and colored thread) for her boutique.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to re-sell

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji lives in Shah Rukn-e-Alam, a part of the city of Multan. Multan is famous for its historical places and handicrafts. Nasreen baji owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for the last 6 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son works in a factory. Her younger son reads in 3rd standard and her daughter reads in 7th standard. Her husband, Mr. T., is a painter who paints houses, windows, and doors.

Nasreen baji is a housewife and has a business of selling clothes. She buys clothes from different cities and sells them in Multan. She has been in this profession for the last 15 years. She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to resell. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy bicycle spare parts for her spare parts shop. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy scrap (plastic bottles and paper) for her scrap business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Sreymom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 19 people in Peam Prochum Village in Kandal Province led by Mrs. Mao S., the Village Bank President. All the members will use the loan for a variety of purposes. For example, Mrs.  S. is a farmer who cultivates twice a year: rice during the raiN. season and vegetables during the dry season. Her husband, Mr. Prak Duong is a construction worker who can eA. around $2 per day. However, they still live in poor conditions, so Mrs. Mao S. is requesting a loan to buy a boat for her husband to start a fishing business. 

Mrs. Mao S. is 48 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending school while the other is of preschool age

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To  buy a boat for her husband to start a fishing business.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji lives in Shah Rukn-e-Alam, a part of the city of Multan. Multan is famous for its historical places and handicrafts. She owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for the past 25 years. She is the mother of seven children: two sons and five daughters. Her elder son works in a hospital. The other children are getting their educations. Naseem baji's husband, R. M., is a worker in an organization named "Saeed Building."

Naseem baji has a business of selling clothes. She has 20 years of experience. She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Saba baji wants a loan to buy supplies (telephone set and wires) to make a telephone booth. Safia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Zareena baji wants a loan to buy chickens for her chicken meat business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida baji lives in Shah Rukn-e-Alam, a part of the city of Multan. Multan is famous for its historical places and handicrafts. Her house consists of one large room, one wash room, and an open kitchen. She has been living there for the last 20 years. Khalida baji is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a driver and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Her younger son is in 5th standard and her daughter reads in 4th standard. Her husband, R. H., works in a factory.

Khalida baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her children. She is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her elder son.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Zubaida baji and Shamim baji each want a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread, and cloth) for their decorative embroidery businesses. Rashida baji wants a loan to buy bicycle spare parts for her spare parts shop. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Elgun

texts.en:
Elgun was born in 1986 and is single. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Fuzuli region in Azerbaijan.

Elgun has been in the clothing sales business for a year. Now, this young man needs a loan of $1200 USD to buy more clothing to expand and improve his business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to expand and increase his business

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
María Isabel M. lives in the municipality of Lourdes, along with her husband who is a salaried employee. They have a large family as is the custom in this country. To support his four children, 7 years ago María Isabel started as small store selling homegrown produce and through hard effort and work managed to expand her small business and put up a store selling basic products.

Due to the complicated economic situation in the country, María has been forced to look for alternative ways to make money, putting up a tortilla store to augment the store. Her oldest daughter helps daily in the store and is currently a university student and her studies are paid for by her parents. The M. family is requesting a loan in order to be able to buy more products for the family store that will allow it to develop and grow economically.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

María Isabel M. vive en el municipio D. Lourdes, junto a su esposo, quien es empleado asalariado, mantienen una familia granD., como es costumbre en el país. Para mantener a sus cuatro hijos, María Isabel inicia hace 7 años con una pequeña venta D. verduras casera, mediante esfuerzo y trabajo arduo logro expandir su pequeño negocio y monta una tienda D. productos básicos. Debido a la complicada situación económica nacional, María se ha visto obligada a buscar formas alternativas D. generar ingresos, poniendo una venta D. tortillas para complementar la tienda. Su hija mayor ayuda diariamente en la venta y cursa actualmente sus estudios universitarios, que le son pagados por sus padres. La familia M. solicita un préstamo para así poder comprar más insumos para la tienda familiar, que les permita desarrollarse y crecer tanto económica como integralmente.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies to reinvest in business

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Daniel F. B. lives in Coatepeque, Santa Ana in the western region of El Salvador along with his wife and four daughters. After four years of continuos work Daniel provides his family, managing a business selling fruits in the area the most traffic in his town, a story which is a living testimony of Daniel's effort and faith. He started the business with only $400. Two of Daniel's daughters have finished their high school studies and the youngest is in 3rd grade. Faithful to his vision of progress and offering a better future to his daughter, Daniel is requesting a loan to reinvest in his business and to boost its growth, that will provide a better future for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Daniel F. B. vive en un cantón de Coatepeque, Santa Ana en la zona occidental del país, donde reside junto a su esposa y cuatro hijas. Tras cuatro años de trabajo continuo Daniel provee a su familia, manejando un negocio de venta de verduras en la zona más transitada de su pueblo, historia que es un vivo testimonio del esfuerzo y la fe de Daniel, pues lo inició con tan solo $400. Dos de las hijas de Daniel, se encuentran terminando sus estudios colegiales, en el bachillerato, mientras la más pequeña de las tres cursa primaria. Fiel a su visión de progreso y de ofrecer un mejor futuro para sus hijas, Daniel solicita un préstamo para reinvertir en su negocio y potenciar su crecimiento, que trace un mejor porvenir para su familia.

loans.use: Reinvestment in business

loans.name: Elmidar

texts.en:
Elmidar has been in the taxi business for ten years. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Agdam region in Azerbaijan. He has settled in the town of Khirdalan, where he is married with two children.

Elmidar is requesting a loan of $1200 USD to buy spare car parts that he needs to improve his taxi business.

loans.use: To buy spare car parts to improve his taxi business

loans.name: Elmer

texts.es:
Mr. Elmer F. lives in the Lourdes districtt in the province of La Libertad along with his wife. At 60 years of age, Elmer needs to work two jobs to maintain his household. In addition to doing traditional agricultural work, he also works in transportation, making trips for his local church. His wife helps also, having a sewing business which she manages from their house. Their many fixed expenses have obliged them to postpone necessary repairs and improvements for their house. One of these improvements is the roof above the hallway in the house, which has been impossible for them to repair due to them having to prioritize their expenses in order to survive. That's why he is requesting a loan to install a new roof over the hallway of the house since the current one has significant damage.

It should be mentioned that this will be the first loan for Elmer with Integral, although he has already had several loans from various cooperatives that he has repaid with promptness and responsibility.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Elmer F., vive en el cantón Lourdes jurisdicción del Departamento de La Libertad, junto a su esposa. A sus 60 años, Don Elmer se ve obligado a realizar dos trabajos para mantener su casa. Además de dedicarse a la tradicional labor de la agricultura, también trabaja como transportista, efectuando viajes para una iglesia local. A los esfuerzos de lucha, se suma su esposa, quién tiene un negocio de costura el cual maneja desde su propia casa. Sus múltiples gastos fijos los han obligado a posponer arreglos y mejorías necesarias para su vivienda. Una de estas mejoras, es el techo del corredor de su vivienda, el cual les ha sido imposible remodelar debido a que han tenido que priorizar sus gastos para subsistir. Debido a ello esta solicitando un préstamo para instalar un nuevo techo en el corredor de la casa, ya que el techo actual muestra daños significativos. Cabe mencionar que para Don Elmer será el primer préstamo con Integral, auque ya ha tenido varios créditos con cooperativas, los cuales ha pagado con prontitud y responsabilidad.

loans.use: Roof installation in house

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en:
Tahira (her saleswoman is pictured) was born in 1966. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Kalbadjar region in Azerbaijan. She has settled in the town of Khirdalan, where she has been running a spare parts business for ten years.

Tahira is requesting a loan of $1200 USD to buy additional spare parts to increase and improve her business.

loans.use: To buy additional spare parts to increase and improve her business

loans.name: Avaz

texts.en: Avaz was born in 1963. This man is married and has 3 children. Avaz is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Lachin region in Azerbaijan and has settled in Khirdalan town. Now Avaz needs a loan of US$ 1200 to buy the  necessary spare parts for repairing cars. He has been in this business for 15 years.

loans.use: to buy the necessary spare parts for repairing cars

loans.name: Tem

texts.en:
Mrs. Tem R. is a farmer in Thmei Khmer Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, and her husband, Mr. Lon Song, is a firewood seller whose small income helps to support the family. Currently, Mrs. R. is requesting a loan to buy an additional ox to pair with the old one in order to cultivate her field. 

Mrs. R. is 53 years old and the mother of two children who are attending school. Previously, she obtained a loan, now fully repaid, to buy a piece of land for rice cultivation.

loans.use: To buy an additional ox to pair with the old one in order to cultivate her rice field

loans.name: Chamroen

texts.en:
Mrs. Chamroen N., 41, is a farmer while her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. They live in Vatamim Commune, Battambang Province. Chamroen has five children, all of whom live in the family's home and attend school. She has been growing rice since 1996 and the rice crop provides the main income for her family. She always takes care of this business. 

It is rice growing season in Cambodia. In order to increase the family's income, she would like to request a loan to plow more farmland, and also to purchase fertilizer in order to increase the rice yield. This loan will allow her to improve their living conditions. Chamroen and her husband are pictured with their children.

loans.use: To plow more farmland and purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
This the second time for Mrs. Soy P. to ask for a loan to improve her living conditions. She is a farmer in Ra village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Nak Nan, is a construction worker and pig breeder who raises two pigs. Mrs. Soy P. is 45 and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one is a construction worker. The remaining three are attending school.

Although this family has different business activities, they still live in an old house and poor conditions. In order to improve her standard of living, Mrs. Soy P. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Previously, Mrs. Soy P. had obtained a loan to buy pigs for breeding. She has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Edisa

texts.en:
Edisa is a 30-year-old woman from a small place called Duborovci near the town of Gračanica. She is a housewife and she does tailoring at home. Edisa has two sewing machines at home and she can earn about 300 KM (~ $210 USD) each month by making clothes and new suits. 

This is Edisa' fifth loan from Women for Women Internation and it is for $475 USD. She will use this loan to buy additional material and sewing equipment that she needs for her work. She needs additional money for school for her two children, and they need more money to buy books and notebooks.

loans.use: To buy additional material and equipment for sewing.

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Mrs. Khun A. is a villager in Ra Village in Kampong ChhnA. Province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Phin Chin, is a pot seller who transports pots to sell door-to-door. In Mrs. Khun A.’s plantation, she now faces a small problem because her plantation revenue is too small. In order to expand it, Mrs. Khun A. decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to cultivate rice.

Mrs. Khun A. is 44 years old and the mother of seven children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another one helps the father with his business. Three more are attending school while the remaining two are too young to work or study. Previously, Mrs. Khun A. had obtained a loan to start her husband's business. She has succeeded in paying off the prior loan.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun C. is 37 years old and works on a plot of land growing rice to earn a living to support her family. She also raises pigs to earn an extra income as well.

Planting rice has been a difficult job, as there is high inflation and weather conditions have not been conducive to a good growing season. In most of the provinces there are no irrigation systems yet, so farmers have to farm by depending on the sky. They all are very happy when they see the clouds are dark but if there is no rain they will face crop damage.

On average, Bun C. is able to earn around $7 each day. She has three children and all of them are students. She told a loan officer that she wants all her children to take a higher class. She does not want her children to grow rice like her because this work is so difficult and you earn less to support the family.

Bun C. is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to invest in her existing business. She would like to both invest US$ 500 in her farm, and also put US$ 700 into raising animals, increasing her livestock. She sees these investments as opportunities that will be able to increase her daily income.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: invest US$ 500 in her farm and US$ 700 into her livestock

loans.name: Zineta

texts.en: Zineta was born in 1959. She is a widow and lives in Gračanica where she works in a shoe factory for a monthly salary of 600 KM. This is her first loan from Women for Women international and she will use the 1000 KM to buy a sole sewing machine in order to work at home in her free time and earn extra money for her household.

loans.use: To buy sole sewing machine.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ean

texts.en:
Mrs. Ean N. is a 42-year-old widowed factory worker living in Khsang Cheung Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the third is attending school. 

Although three of the family members are employed, living conditions in their old house are poor. In order to improve upon those conditions, Mrs. Ean N. is requesting a loan to add to her savings to build a new house.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for better living conditions

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Mrs. Ou S. is a 52-year-old widowed farmer who cultivates twice a year in Khsang Thbong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province.  She has four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another one is a primary school teacher who can make $30 per month to support the family. The remaining one is attending school. 

Even though the family members are gainfully employed, their lives do not improve and they live in an old house. Thus, Mrs. Ou S. is requesting a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for her family

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
Chin L., age 46, is married and lives in Phnom Penh. She is a farmer who plants a variety of vegetables, such as cucumbers. Her husband is a fisherman, and he also helps his wife plant vegetables. This couple together is able to earn a living of around US$10 in revenue per day. They have eight children, of whom four are students and three others are self-employed, one as a sculptor and another as a construction foreman. Mrs. L. would like a Kiva loan via CREDIT, Kiva’s Field Partner, of US$1200 to purchase more wood for her son's sculpture business.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for her son's sculpture business.

loans.name: Abc Group
loans.use: Buy AA

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Heng S., 34, has two children -- one 3 years old and one 7, who studies in kindergarten. He works with his wife selling various kinds of grocery products to the people in their community. He can typically earn about $4/day of net income. Each month, Mr. Heng S. spends around $40 on food, $20 on utilities and around $10 on his children's tuition fees, and sometimes the family members will spend a little more on a special occasion such as a wedding party, funeral ceremony, or other traditional ceremony.

Mr. Heng S. and his wife would like to ask for a loan from Kiva to purchaS. more grocery products to increaS. their profit margin as well as to meet their growing customer demand.

In the future, this couple plans to expand his stand to enable them to grow the business more.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to meet his clients' demands.

loans.name: Vahdeta

texts.en:
Vahdeta was born in 1989 and she lives in a suburb of the town of Doboj called Sjenina Rijeka. She has just started working in the textile industry and, in her free time, she sells clothes and cosmetics. 

With this loan of 700 KM, Vahdeta will purchase additional clothes and cosmetics to sell. 

She hopes that she will earn more money, because her husband's salary of 600 KM (~ $420 USD) is not enough for their new life. They are a newly married couple and they need money to start from the beginning.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Luch

texts.en:
Luch Y. is 51 years old and works as a tailor from her home. Her business has been around for about ten years, and she makes US$5 each day. Her daughter, Touch Nita, age 20, is a garment worker and earns a living of around US$3 per day. Mrs. Luch would like a loan from Kiva of US$1200 to purchase more cloth for her tailoring business.

CREDIT MFI (Kiva’s Field Partner) is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Nem

texts.en:
This is the second time for Mr. Nem R. to ask for a loan to improve his living conditions. He lives in Hang Chhouk Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He is a construction worker who can earn around $3 per day to support his family. Aside from this, he is a pig breeder. His wife, Mrs. Hoeurn Ven, is a farmer. In this farming, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough animal to plow her rice field.

Mr. Nem R. decided to ask for a loan to buy one more ox to plow with the old one in order to cultivate rice. Mr. Nem R. is 47 years old and the father of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the remaining three are attending school. Previously, Mr. Nem R. had obtained a loan to buy piglets for breeding. He has fully paid back the prior loan.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy one more ox to plow with the old one in order to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Srin

texts.en:
Srin V., age 41, is a mother of four children and lives in an outlying area. Since 2005, she and her husband have been working on farming and raising animals. This couple together is able to earn a living around $5 of profit per day. Mrs. Srin V. would like to borrow from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, a loan of US$1200 to purchase more piglets for her stock and buy feed for them as well.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs

loans.name: Choun

texts.en:
Mrs. Choun T. is a 50-year-old farmer who cultivates twice a year in Hang Chhouk Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, while her husband, Mr. Kruy Seng, is a motorbike taxi driver whose small salary helps support the household. They are the parents of five children, three of whom are attending school while the others are too young to work or study. 

Since this family has only two businesses, they cannot afford to build a new house. Therefore, Mrs. T. is requesting a loan to add to her savings to build a new house in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house to improve the family's living conditions.

loans.name: Denisa

texts.en: Denisa is a 23-year-old married woman from Gračanica. She is a housewife, but her husband has a full-time job and he earns about 1000 KM (~ $700 USD) monthly. She already raises chickens and, with this loan of 800 KM, she will buy more chickens and tools for chicken breeding. Her wish is to become the chicken producer for her region and maybe for other towns beyond.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken food

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam N. lives in Hang Chhouk Village in Kampong Chhnang Province where she is a garment factory worker. Her husband, Mr. Phin Eing, is a construction worker and farmer. Unfortunately, his field is infertile, so Mrs. N. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field. 

Mrs. Sam N. is 31 and the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in school while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her husband's field

loans.name: Kimhong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimhong H. is a 27 year old farmer who has been farming since 1992, earning about $4.00 per day. Her husband, Mr. Som Soeun, is 35 years old and raises pigs. He is also a layman in his Village, earning $4.00 per day. Kimhong has one child who lives with them in Snam Preah Commune, Seam Reap Province.

Because of increasing transportation costs, Kimhong decided to request a loan of $1100 to add to her savings to purchase a motorcycle. This will be used by the family to reduce transportation costs. The loan will improve her business and sustain her family's living. Kimhong's husband is pictured because Kimhong was unavailable.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Assetou

texts.fr:
Madame Assétou S. est une veuve âgée de  28 ans,  mére de 4 enfants( 2 garçons et de 2 filles) qui vit dans le domicile de son feu mari à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo( Région de Sikasso  République du Mali).
Elle a commencé très jeune les activités économiques et s’est spécialisée dans un secteur où il ya une forte demande à savoir la vente des pagnes wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’Ouest) depuis maintenant plusieurs années.
En raison des difficultés d’obtenir des ressources financières suffisantes, elle intégra le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir obtenu trois prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) elle est à  son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté.  Avec ce prêt elle compte achéter 12 pièces de pagnes wax à Bobo Dioulasso (une ville de la République de Burkina Faso en Afrique de l’ouest). Elle revend ses pagnes en détail et au comptant dans les foires des villages environnans et dans la ville de Kadiolo (préfecture de Sikasso) à une clientèle essentiellement féminine.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, assurer certaines de ses propres dépenses et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Assétou S. is a widow of 28 years of age, mother of 4 children (two sons and two daughters), who lives in the home of her deceased husband in Koko, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Kadiolo (Sikasso Region, Republic of Mali).

She began to earn her living at a very young age and has specialized in an area where the demand is very high, selling wax print cloth (brightly colored cloth that is highly prized in West Africa) for several years now.

Because of the difficulty of obtaining sufficient financial resources, she joined the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having obtained 3 group loans, she is now on her second individual loan, and all the preceding loans have been reimbursed without difficulty. With this loan she intends to buy 12 lengths of wax print (known as "pagnes") in Bobo Dioulasso (a town in the Republic of Burkina Faso in West Africa). She re-sells her lengths of cloth retail and for cash in the fairs of the surrounding villages and the town of Kadiolo (Sikasso Prefecture) to an essentially female clientele.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 70,000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and cover some of her own expenses, with any remainder being invested back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of lengths of wax print cloth

loans.name: Darrah

texts.fr:
Madame Darrah Maïga est âgée de  53  ans et vit avec ses 4 enfants( 3 garçons et 1 fille)et son mari à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo(une des préfectures de la troisième région économique de la république du Mali).
Dès son jeune âge, elle a commencé les activités économiques notamment la restauration qu’elle a apprise  auprès de sa mère depuis maintenant 20 ans. Elle travaille avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 4 ans et est à son troisième prêt indivuduel, après avoir bouclé sept prêts de groupe ( prêt solidaire)  avec une assocaition de son quartier. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés
Ce prêt servira à  l’achat de 100 Kilogrammes de riz, 50 kilogrammes d’arachide,  5 régimes de bananes, 100kg de d’oranges, 2 chargements de bois de chauffe et d’importantes quantités de condiments  alimentaires   pour  une période  d’un   mois.
Elle  s’approvisionne sur place( à Kadiolo) en fruits et légumes. Le  riz  et condiments alimentaires dans les differents marchés de la ville de Sikasso ou de  Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes spécialisés des domaines concernés.
Elle prépare plusieurs plats: riz au gras, à la sauce tomate, gombo  et arachide,  les soupes de viande, de  pintade,  de  poulet  et de poisson.  Son lieu de vente se trouve au  grand marché de la ville de Kadiolo où il ya une grande affluence d’individus comme les voyageurs, les employés de commerce  et  les  routiers.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel d’environ 80 000 FCFA.qui servira à contribuer aux dépenses familiales et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Madame Darrah Maïga is 53 years old and lives with her four children (three boys and one girl) and her husband in Koko, one of the neighborhoods of Kadiolo (a prefecture of the third-largest economic region of the Republic of Mali). At a young age she started off in the restaurant business, which she learned from her mother for over 20 years. She has been working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for four years and is on her third individual loan after having completed seven group loans (solidarity loans) with an association in her neighborhood. All of the previous loans were properly paid back. This loan will be used to purchase 100 kg of rice, 50 kg of peanuts, five bunches of bananas, 100 kg of oranges, two loads of cooking wood, and large quantities of seasonings for a month. She stocks her fruits and vegetables on-site. The rice and seasonings are bought in the various markets in Sikasso or Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers who specialize in the product concerned. She cooks several dishes: "riz au gras" (similar to rice pilaf), rice with tomato sauce, rice with okra and peanuts, meat soups, guinea fowl, chicken, and fish. Her sales site is in the main market in the town of Kadiolo where there are crowds of individuals such as travelers, business people, and drivers. she envisions making a monthly profit of around 80,000 Francs CFA that will be used to contribute to family expenses and the rest will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for restaurant

loans.name: Lala Lemou

texts.fr:
Madame Lala Lemou Traoré a 44 ans et  vit avec ses 5 enfants et son mari à Noumousso, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo (une des préfectures de la troisième région économique de la république du Mali)
Elle a commencé très tôt les activités commerciales après avoir arreté les études pour des raisons sociales. Elle mème l’activité de vente de graines d’encense, des pagnes wax et des bazins teints(tissus très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest) depuis 14 ans 
Dans sa recherche de ressources financières, elle décida de rejoindre une association de crédit solidaire de son quartier avec laquelle elle a obtenu cinq prêts. Elle est à son cinquième prêt individuel avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte achèter 10 pièces de bazins(moins riche) 30kg de graines d’encens, 40 sachets de collorants et accessoires pour la teinture, 5 types de parfums et des ingrédients pour l’encense.
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) par commande et cela une fois par mois. Elle achète les bazins blancs  les teint , ensuite  les coud tout comme les pagnes wax en Boubou afin de les vendre  dans la ville de Kadiolo, Sikasso et à Abidjan (capitale économique de la République de Côte d’Ivoire).L’encense souvant en graine ou confectionné, est vendu surtout aux femmes essentiellement sur place à Kadiolo où les villages voisins viennent s’y ravitailler. Cette activité est menèe durant toute l’année sans difficultés majeures. La rotation de son activité est très élévée et elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA. 
Madame Lala Lemou Traoré compte augmenter la taille de son activité et vendre sa production sur d’autres marchés.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lala Lemou Traoré is 44 years old and lives with her 5 children and her husband in Moumousso, an area in the city of Kadiolo (one of the prefectures in the third economic region of the republic of Mali). She began engaging in business activities very early on, after having ended her studies for socio-economic reasons. She runs a business selling incense beads, pagnes-wax (a brightly coloured West African cloth), and dyed damask (a highly-prized fabric in West Africa) for 14 years. In her search for financial resources, she decided to join a group credit association in her area, with whom she obtained five loans. She is on her fifth individual loan with the loan program of the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, and all of her previous loans have been repaid properly. With this loan, she intends to buy 10 lengths of damask (less rich), 30kg of incense seeds, 40 bags of dye and dyeing accessories, and 5 types of perfume and ingredients for incense. She supplies herself in Bamako (the capital of the republic of Mali) by order once a month. She buys lengths of white damask, dyes them, and then sews them as pagnes wax in Boubou in order to sell them in the cities of Kadiolo, Sikasso, and Abidjan (the economic capital of the republic of Côte d'Ivoire). The incense, often in grain or processed form, is sold primarily to women essentially on-the-spot in Kadiolo, where people from the neighbouring villages come to resupply themselves. This business is run throughout the year without major difficulties. The turnover of her business is very high, and she intends to realize a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA. Mrs. Lala Lemou Traoré intends to increase the size of her business and to sell her wares at new markets.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagnes wax, incense beads, damask, and dyeing supplies

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Khosrov

texts.en:
Khosrov (his mother is pictured above) was born in 1982. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Kalbadjar region in Azerbaijan. He has settled in the town of Khirdalan, where he is married with one child. He has been running a general store for five years.

Khosrov is requesting a loan of $1200 USD to buy additional food items to increase business and improve their general store.

loans.use: To buy additional food items to increase business and improve their general store

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Siaka Koné est âgé de  30 ans et vit avec ses  3 enfants et son épouse dans une famille monogame à Noumouso, un des quartiers de la ville de kadiolo (Région de Sikasso République du Mali). 
Après plusieurs activités économiques sans succès, il s’est spécialisé dans l’achat vente des produits céréaliers(maïs, sorgho, mil, riz, pois de terre etc) depuis  maintenant  plusieurs années.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à sa prémière expérience 
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter 600kg de maïs et 400kg de sorgho sur place  à Kadiolo et dans les villages environnants généralement les jours de foires hebdomadaires auprès de producteurs céréaliers.
Il les  revend  le plus souvent en gros  au comptant  aux achéteurs qui viennent  des grandes villes telles  Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali) ou  Sikasso et quelques fois en détail et au comptant dans la ville de Kadiolo.  La plupart de sa clientèle est constituée d’hommes.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel  de 60 000 FCFA qu’il utilisera pour payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans ses affaires.
texts.en:
Mr. Siaka Koné is 30 years old and lives with his 3 children and wife in a monogamous household in Noumouso, one of the districts in the city of Kadiolo (in the Sikasso Region of the Republic of Mali). After trying several business activities without success, he has specialized in the purchase and sale of cereal products (maize, sorghum, millets, rice, groundnuts, etc) for several years now. In his search for supplementary financial resources in order to satisfy the needs of his increasingly growing clientele, he decided to join the credit program run by the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which whom he is seeking his first loan. With this loan, he intends to buy 600kg of maize and 400kg of sorghum on-the-spot from the cereal producers in Kadiolo and in the surrounding villages, generally during the weekly fairs. He most often re-sells the grains wholesale in cash to buyers who come from large cities such as Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali) or Sikasso. He also sometimes sells at retail in cash in the city of Kadiolo. The majority of his clientele consists of men. He foresees realizing a monthly profit of 60,000 FCFA, which he will use to pay off the loan, investing the remainder in his business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals (maize and sorghum)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Mohtaram

texts.en: 8 years ago, Mohtaram started this business. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Lachin region in Azerbaijan and has settled in Khirdalan town. This man is married and has 3 children. Now he needs a loan of US$ 625 to buy the meat necessary to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy meat for re-sale

loans.name: Wana

texts.fr:
Madame Wana B.  a 39 ans, mére de 1 garçon et de 2 filles  et  vit avec son époux dans une famille monogame à Koko, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo (une préfecture de la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Pour des raisons socio économique ( issue d’une famille nomade d’éléveurs “Maure”) elle n’a pas fréquentée l’école, mais très tôt s’est interessée à l’activité familliale à savoir le colportage (des produits du sud vers le nord et inversement) qu’elle a apprise et maitrisée auprès de sa mère. Elle s’est spécialisée dans la  vente de tubercules ,des condiments alimentaires,des poissons(fumé et séché) des tapis etc il y’a de cela 7 ans.   
 Pour obtenir des réssources financières complémentaires elle décida de travailler avec le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  trois ans . Elle est à son premier prêt individuel après avoir bouclé 3 prêts solidaires au sein d’une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Fotémogoban de Kadiolo ville)
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter au marché de Medine à Sikasso ville  900kg de pomme de terre et 60 sacs de choux pommés pour aller les vendre à Gao ( 7eme région administrative située au septentrion de la république du Mali) et de retour achèter 2 tapis (moyen  et grand format), 3 sacs de poissons( dont 2 fumé et 1 sèché) pour les revendre à Kadiolo à domicile et au marché.  Sa clientèle est généralement constituée de femmes
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000FCFA, qui la permettra de résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Wana B., 39 years old, is the mother of 1 boy and 2 girls, and lives with her husband in a monogamous household in Koko, one of the districts of the city of Kadiolo (a prefecture of the third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). For socio-economic reasons (having come from a nomadic "Maure" family of cattle-rearers), she did not go to school, but became interested very early on in the family business of colportage (the transfer of goods from the south to the north and vice versa), which she learned and mastered with her mother. She has specialized in the sale of tubers, food condiments, fish (smoked and dried), carpets, etc. for 7 years now. To obtain supplementary financial resources, she has been working with the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso for three years now. She is on her first individual loan after having completed 3 group loans as part of an association of women from her area (Association Fotémogoban of Kadiolo). With this loan, she plans to buy 900kg of potatoes and 60 bags of round cabbage from the Medine market in Sikasso to go and sell in Gao (the 7th administrative region of the Republic of Mali, situated in the northern region), and in return buy 2 carpets (medium and large size), 3 bags of fish (2 smoked and 1 dried) to re-sell in Kadiolo at home and at the market. Her clientele generally consists of women. She foresees realizing a monthly profit of 70,000 FCFA, which will allow her to settle her family's expenses, pay off the loan, and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy potatoes and cabbage

loans.name: Moinposho

texts.en: G. Moinposho is 39 years old. She is an experienced business woman and a mother of three children. For the last twelve years, Moinposho has been working in her community and, by now, is a well-known seamstress. Five years ago, Moinposho decided to take advantage of her reputation and opened her own shop. The entrepreneur now has a well-established clientele, the majority of whom are parents of school-going children. Moinposho also constantly adds new clients and is thereby continuously expanding her business. Moinposho has been an active and strongly-motivated client of IMON since 2006. Her credit history makes her eligible to receive new and larger loans. Currently, she is requesting a loan of US$600 for a term of 10 months to be able to purchase new, modern fabrics for sewing the national dresses. Moinposho and her family are thankful to everyone for generosity and support.

loans.use: Purchase of new, modern fabrics for sewing the national dresses

loans.name: Shavkatjon

texts.en: H. Shavkatjon is 41 years old. He is married and has five children. Due to the lack of employment options in his country, it was difficult for Shavkatjon to find work and financially support his family. Therefore, 12 years ago, he decided to start his own business selling men's shoes. Shavkatjon has been receiving financial help through IMON for the past 3 years, and it has helped his business grow. Little by little, Shavkatjon has been able to expand his inventory and, thanks to the good service he offers, his business is now growing rapidly. Currently, however, Shavkatjon needs a loan of US$1,000 which he will use to buy additional merchandise to meet the demand of his clients and to continue expanding his sales business. Shavkatjon is committed to paying back the loan within 9 months. Throughout his career, he has acquired such qualities as perseverance and stamina, and they will also now help him succeed in repaying the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of new men's shoes for sale

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mr. Yan S., 37, and his wife, Mrs. My Mon, 40, live in a small village off of National Road Two about eighteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of their children are in school locally, and the other one is still young and stays at home.

Mr. Yan S. has been a Remoque Motor Taxi driver for seventeen years. Remoque is a motorbike with a trailer at the back. He carries people and goods from his village to Phnom Penh City. His wife has been a garment factory worker for six years. The couple is in the process of building their new house and lacks the money to finish it. So, Yan is requesting a loan of US$1000 to combine with his own money to purchase materials to build a new house.

loans.use: To purchase materials to build a new house for his family

loans.name: Abdumanon

texts.en: I. Abdumanon is 48 years old. He is married and has two children. Abdumanon is an entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuffs, including sweets, soft drinks, and juice, in the grocery store which he rents. Abdumanon is not alone in this business - his entire family actively helps him with the sales. Abdumanon has already previously received financial help through IMON. The financial assistance he has received has helped him expand his business. Currently, Abdumanon has about US$1,000 in inventory, while his gross income is about US$900 and his monthly net profit is about US$300. Abdumanon, however, needs a loan of US$1,075 for a term of 8 months to be able to increase the stock of goods in his store. He is ready to work hard and make sacrifices to become an even more successful entrepreneur. Abdumanon's perseverance and clear vision, too, will help him succeed in his small business.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mr. Soeun S., 60, and his wife, Mrs. Loeung Nget, 58, live in a small village off of National Road Two about eighteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1980 and have nine children: four sons and five daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home. Four children are garment factory workers, and the other two children study in a local school.

Soeun has been a motorbike repairer for fifteen years. He runs his business from his shop in the village, while his wife raises pigs at home. Everyday many customers come to his shop, and he needs to buy more spare parts to serve them, but lacks the money. Therefore, Soeun is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase motorbike spare parts for his business and to buy piglets for his wife to raise at home.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike spare parts for resale and to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Radjabmoh

texts.en: K. Radjabmoh is 41 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Radjabmoh’s husband works as a taxi driver in their community. In order to supplement her husband's income, Radjabmoh has been running her own business for the past ten years. She sells the national trousers for women. The national dresses and trousers in Tajikistan are very popular among both girls and older women. Radjabmoh sells clothing at the central markets of Dushanbe city. She tries to offer a wide range of goods to be able to meet the requirements of all of her customers who have different tastes and levels of income. Currently, Radjabmoh needs a loan of US$1,000 to purchase additional women's trousers for sale. She promises to repay the loan within 9 months and is thankful for everyone's support.

loans.use: Purchase of new women's national trousers for sale

loans.name: Sovan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovan P., 42, and her husband, Mr. Savuth Chem, 44, live in a Phnom Penh suburb. They were married in 1985 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Their daughter is married and lives in the family home, and their son is a truck driver. He purchases and hauls dirt to sell to villagers for leveling their house foundations.

Mrs. Sovan has been farming since she was young. She grows rice in the village. Besides farming, she sells dessert in Phnom Penh. Her husband is an army soldier, but now he is sick and staying at home.

Now Sovan is requesting a loan of US$1200 to expand her son's business of purchasing and hauling dirt to sell for leveling house foundations.

loans.use: To expand her son's business of purchasing and hauling dirt to sell for leveling house foundations.

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en:
M. Nodira is 34 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Nodira has been selling sportswear for men and boys for the past 11 years. She started the sales business because she had been out of work for some time, and her children's necessities could not be paid for with her husband’s income alone. Nodira decided to use her savings to buy sportswear from wholesale vendors and, in turn, sell it in the local market. Little by little, she has managed to increase her customer base and to make enough income to support her 4 children.

At present, however, the selection of garments in Nodira's inventory is poor, and she therefore needs a loan of US$1,000 to be repaid in 6 months. With the help of the loan, Nodira will be able to purchase new and more diverse merchandise to offer to her clients. With your support, Nodira will eventually be able to expand her business and save money for her children’s future expenses.

loans.use: Purchase sportswear for men and boys

loans.name: Soksan

texts.en:
Mrs. Soksan P. (show in the picture on the lelf with ther mother), 23, and her husband were married in 2004 and have one son. The couple lives with Soksan's parents on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Soksan has been a silk weaver since 2000, a skill she learned from her mother, while her husband is a silk weaver as well. Soksan sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Currently, she is creating another business of selling grocery items in front of her house, but lacks the money to buy them for resale. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase grocery items for her new store.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en: M. Nazira is 35 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Her husband left her six years ago; since then, Nazira has been raising her children alone and has been their sole provider. She earns income selling clothing for children, and, thanks to her perseverance and dedication to her work, little by little the business has progressed and resulted in increasing satisfaction and joy to Nazira herself. Her hard work has also helped improve the quality of life for her family. In the future, however, Nazira would like to further increase the income generated from the business in order to be able to pay for her children's studies. To achieve this goal, Nazira is asking for a loan of US$ 600 for a term of 9 months, which she will use to purchase additional children's clothing articles for sale. Nazira is an exemplary businesswoman and mother, and will highly appreciate your support.

loans.use: Purchase of additional children's clothing for sale

loans.name: Thach

texts.en:
Mrs. Thach L., 55, and her husband, Mr. Yun Choun, 56, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1972 and have four sons. One of them is married and lives outside the family home. Another two sons are assisting with Yun's business of wooden house construction.

Mrs. Thach has been a silk weaver, using a skill she learned from her mother, after the Pol Pot regime. Thach sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Yun has been building wooden houses for over twenty years. Now Thach is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase blacksmith materials and a generator for her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith material and a generator for her husband's house construction business

loans.name: Fotima

texts.en: R. Fotima is a single mother of six children. She decided to start her own business to be able to support her children, to provide them with education, food, and a home. Fotima began her business 12 years ago, selling products from a catalog. Afterwards, she began helping a friend in her curtain sales business, and later continued to run a similar business independently. Fotima's business currently allows her to cover her family's expenses. However, she would like to expand the business even further to improve her family's standard of living. Therefore, Fotima is asking for a loan of US$1,000 which she will use to buy merchandise and fill her pending orders. Fotima plans to repay the loan within 12 months. She is thankful to everyone for their support.

loans.use: Purchase of new, modern curtains for sale

loans.name: Robiya

texts.en: R. Robiya is 48 years old. She is a single mother and the head of the family. She is raising her two children by herself. For the past five years, Robiya has been engaged in many income-generating activities, particularly, a children's toy sales business, and has been able to pay for her children's food and studies with the business profits. Before starting the sales business, Robiya was running a store at her house. This allowed her to take care of her children, while they assisted her with the clients. Robiya started her children's toy sales business with US $600 from her savings, with additional financial help from her older children. Currently, Robiya still needs additional capital to invest in her business to be able to increase the volume and variety of merchandise. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of US $800 for a term of 12 months, which she will use to purchase additional children's toys for sale. Robiya thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to be responsible with the loan payment.

loans.use: Purchase of children's toys for sale

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en: S. Firuza is 43 years old. She is married and has three children. Firuza owns a small clothing sales business at an outdoor market in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She sells clothing for schoolboys and schoolgirls. Firuza is an experienced entrepreneur, and has been running her business for the past 6 years. She tries to maintain a good selection of clothing in her store to attract the attention of people shopping at the market. Firuza’s business is an important source of income for her family. She makes US$ 200 in a typical month, which is a good middle-class income for Tajikistan. At present, however, Firuza needs a loan of US$ 600 to be able to purchase new inventory of clothing for schoolgirls and schoolboys, given the high demand for such clothing during the current season.

loans.use: Purchase of new clothing for schoolboys and schoolgirls for sale

loans.name: Vahdeta

texts.en:
Vahdeta was born in 1965.  She is from the village Šerići, where she lives with her husband and two sons. Her husband works in a furniture factory in the town of Živinice and earns about 400 KM monthly. 

Vahdeta is in charge of the agriculture and cattle breeding for the family. She sells milk and milk products and can earn about 200 KM monthly. She will use this loan in the amount of 600 KM to buy hay for their cow for the winter. Vahdeta wants to save the money that she earns selling milk and use it to buy another cow in the future.

loans.use: To buy hay for cow.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ismoiljon

texts.en: T. Ismoiljon is 35 years old. He is married and has 6 children. Ismoiljon began earning income selling seasonal vegetables when he was 19 years old by helping his dad. After a while, he began working at other jobs, but realized that his work wasn't bringing in enough income to cover the expenses of his family. Therefore, Ismoiljon decided to independently re-engage in the seasonal vegetable sales business. Gradually, he is becoming known in the area; however, he still needs additional capital to purchase vegetables for sale, given the high demand during the current season. Ismoiljon is asking for a loan of US$600, which he will repay within 4 months. With this money, Ismoiljon will be able to buy additional vegetables for sale and thus earn more profit. Ismoiljon plans to use the additional income to help his children move forward in completing their studies. He is thankful to everyone for support.

loans.use: Purchase of seasonal vegetables for sale

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en:
U. Dilbar is married and describes herself as a hard-working and happy mother of two children. Her husband works as a day laborer. Dilbar decided to start her own tailoring business, since his salary alone would not have allowed the couple to provide their children with good education. Dilbar started out by helping a woman who was running a tailoring shop, and, after she learned the trade, she was offered a paid job. The owner of the shop encouraged Dilbar to eventually start her own business, and, after a while, Dilbar decided to follow the advice and install a small shop in her home. The business to date has been successful, and Dilbar has even been able to expand it.  
Currently, however, she needs a loan of US$300 for a term of 10 months, which she will use to purchase materials to be able to fulfill her customers' requests. Dilbar and her family are very grateful for your support.

loans.use: Purchase of new, modern materials for a tailoring business

loans.name: Sarvinoz

texts.en: V. Sarvinoz is 27 years old, married, and has two children. Her husband works for a security company, while Sarvinoz earns additional income for the family selling women's clothing. She has been incolved in the clothing sales business for the past 3 years. Sarvinoz is a hard-working and dedicated entrepreneur, working every day with a cheerful smile and a desire to meet the needs of her customers. Sarvinoz started her business after having to leave her previous job, and she is grateful for the income the business has provided through the years. Currently, Sarvinoz needs a loan of US$ 900 to meet the increasing amount of business orders. She promises to repay the loan within 9 months, and is thankful to everyone for helping improve her family's income and standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase of new women's and girls' clothing for sale

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy B. is 35 years old. She is a wife and a mother of four kids, who are all currently in school. She loves selling goods, through which she obtains a source of livelihood. She has been selling yams for seven years to support her family. She takes delivery of stock direct from farmers. This enables her to avoid middlemen who buy from the farmers and would resell to her at higher prices.

With this loan, Lucy wants to buy yams in bulk to sell to her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in their schooling. Lucy is a member of a community group called Suro Nyame (meaning Fear God) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret F. is a 38 year old wife and mother of three kids, who are in school. She has been a food vendor for five years.
